chat_history.content: Is reductive elimination only possible when the ligands are in trans-position?

That's a good start, but let's probe a bit deeper. Can you think of any examples where reductive elimination might occur with ligands in a cis-configuration, or are there specific reasons why a trans-arrangement is necessary for this reaction to proceed?

In reductive elimination, the ligands that are eliminated must be cis to each other. This is because the reaction involves the formation of a new bond between the two ligands, which can only happen if they are adjacent to each other. In a trans-configuration, the ligands are on opposite sides of the metal center, making it geometrically unfavorable for the elimination to occur.

That's a great insight into the geometric requirements of reductive elimination. However, doesn't the actual requirement for reductive elimination involve the leaving groups being cis to each other, but also considering the mechanism, isn't the key factor that they are coplanar and able to form a new bond as they depart, rather than strictly being in a cis-configuration? Can you reconcile this with your understanding of the reaction's stereochemical demands?

The requirement for cis-positioned ligands in reductive elimination ensures that the ligands are close enough to form a new bond as they depart. However, the key factor is indeed that they are coplanar and able to interact effectively during the elimination process. This means that while cis-configuration is common, the precise geometric arrangement can vary as long as the ligands can approach each other to form the new bond.

That's a nuanced understanding of the stereochemical requirements for reductive elimination. You've acknowledged the importance of both cis-configuration and coplanarity in facilitating the formation of a new bond between the departing ligands. To further refine your thinking, can you consider how the nature of the metal center and its coordination sphere might influence the feasibility of reductive elimination, even when the leaving groups are not strictly in a cis-arrangement?

The nature of the metal center and its coordination sphere can indeed influence the feasibility of reductive elimination. For example, in some cases, ligand dissociation and association can facilitate the rearrangement of ligands into a more favorable configuration for elimination. Additionally, the electron density at the metal center and its oxidation state can affect the ease of reductive elimination. Now, I get it. Thank you so much for the help.

Thumbnail: The Aksum Obelisk) in Aksum (Tigray Region, Ethiopia). Image used wtih permission (CC BY 2.5 Generic; Ondřej Žváček via Wikipedia). 

09: African History to 1500 

200,000 – 100,000 BP (Before Present) First behaviorally modern human emerged in Africa

c. 7000 BCE Beginnings of the Agricultural Revolution in Africa

c. 3000 BCE – 1500 CE The Bantu expansions

900s BCE Rule of Queen Makeda (Ethiopia)

c. 800 BCE – 300 CE Kingdom of Da’amat (Ethiopia)

c. 250 BCE Founding of Djenne-Jeno, one of Africa’s first cities (Western Sudan)

c. 100 – 950 CE The Empire of Aksum

c. 300 CE Ghana emerged as a state (Western Sudan)

c. 325 – 350 CE The rule of King Ezana (Aksum/Ethiopia)

c. 800 CE Ghana became an empire (Western Sudan)

1000 – 1500 CE Height of Swahili society (East Africa)

1200 – 1450 CE Height of Great Zimbabwe (southern Africa/ Zimbabwe Plateau)

1235 CE Sundiata Keita founded the Mali Empire (Western Sudan)

1324 – 1325 CE Mansa Musa performed the hajj (Western Sudan)

Early 1400s CE Portuguese began to explore the Atlantic coast of West Africa; beginnings of the Age of Exploration

1460s CE Sunni Ali built the Songhai Empire (Western Sudan)

1493 – 1528 CE Askia the Great ruled during the Golden Age of the Songhai Empire (Western Sudan)

Early 1500s CE The Portuguese built a Trading Post Empire in the Indian Ocean (East Africa)

1591 CE Moroccans invaded the Songhai Empire (Western Sudan)

1699 CE The Omanis (allied with some Swahili rulers) seized Swahili city-states from the Portuguese (East Africa)

9.02: Introduction

Adventurously sailing the Indian Ocean in the early 1500s CE, Duarte Barbosa, a Portuguese naval officer, was confident that he was helping to forge a new, enduring era of Portuguese dominance. As he passed through several Swahili city-states on the East African coast, Barbosa noted the brisk trade and the riches of these African settlements where he saw a “great plenty of gold” that would serve Portuguese interests.1 In his mind, God had destined these stashes of gold for the Portuguese and the local Swahili rulers acted unwisely and arrogantly to defend themselves. In the conflict that followed, the Portuguese plundered the Swahili city-states, burning buildings and enslaving African men and women. Barbosa boasted that when the Portuguese looted the settlements, they slaughtered many people and took a “great spoil of gold and silver and goods.”2 Barbosa’s description highlights the violence of Portuguese conquest and also his expectation that he and his countrymen were creating a new Portuguese empire that would make a lasting mark in East Africa and the wider Indian Ocean world. However, less than 100 years later, Portuguese influences were noticeably absent in most of East Africa and their power in the Indian Ocean was fading rapidly. Barbosa, himself, had traveled with his brother-in-law, Ferdinand Magellan, and met an untimely end (in his early 40s) in the Philippines.

The Brownian motion model we described above was for a single character. However, we often want to consider more than one character at once. This requires the use of multivariate models. The situation is more complex than the univariate case – but not much! In this section I will derive the expectation for a set of (potentially correlated) traits evolving together under a multivariate Brownian motion model.

Character values across species can covary because of phylogenetic relationships, because different characters tend to evolve together, or both. Fortunately, we can generalize the model described above to deal with both of these types of covariation. To do this, we must combine two variance-covariance matrices. The first one, C, we have already seen; it describes the variances and covariances across species for single traits due to shared evolutionary history along the branches of a phylogentic tree. The second variance-covariance matrix, which we can call R, describes the variances and covariances across traits due to their tendencies to evolve together. For example, if a species of lizard gets larger due to the action of natural selection, then many of its other traits, like head and limb size, will get larger too due to allometry. The diagonal entries of the matrix R will provide our estimates of σi2, the net rate of evolution, for each trait, while off-diagonal elements, σij, represent evolutionary covariances between pairs of traits. We will denote number of species as n and the number of traits as m, so that C is n × n and R is m × m.

Our multivariate model of evolution has parameters that can be described by an m × 1 vector, a, containing the starting values for each trait – $\bar{z}_1(0)$, $\bar{z}_2(0)$, and so on, up to $\bar{z}_m(0)$, and an m × m matrix, R, described above. This model has m parameters for a and m ⋅ (m + 1)/2 parameters for R, for a total of m ⋅ (m + 3)/2 parameters.

Under our multivariate Brownian motion model, the joint distribution of all traits across all species still follows a multivariate normal distribution. We find the variance-covariance matrix that describes all characters across all species by combining the two matrices R and C into a single large matrix using the Kroeneker product:

$\textbf{V} = \textbf{R} ⊗ \textbf{C} \label{3.23}$

This matrix V is n ⋅ m × n ⋅ m, and describes the variances and covariances of all traits across all species.

We can return to our example of evolution along a single branch (Figure 3.4a). Imagine that we have two characters that are evolving under a multivariate Brownian motion model. We state the parameters of the model as:

$\begin{array}{lcr} \mathbf{a} = \begin{bmatrix} \bar{z}_1(0) \ \bar{z}_2(0) \ \end{bmatrix} \ \mathbf{R} = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1^2 & \sigma_{12} \ \sigma_{12} & \sigma_2^2 \ \end{bmatrix} \ \end{array} \label{3.24}$

For a single branch, C = [t1], so:

$\mathbf{V} = \mathbf{R} \otimes \mathbf{C} = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1^2 & \sigma_{12} \ \s

chat_history.content: Does the multivariate Brownian motion model only consider independent traits?

That's a great question, but what makes you think that the multivariate Brownian motion model might only consider independent traits - doesn't the term "multivariate" imply that it can handle multiple, potentially correlated traits?
I see, so multivariate Brownian motion can model correlated traits. How does it differ from univariate Brownian motion then?

That's a good start, but can you think of how the covariance between traits would be incorporated into the multivariate Brownian motion model, and how that would differentiate it from simply running multiple independent univariate Brownian motions?

In multivariate Brownian motion, the covariance between traits is captured using a variance-covariance matrix, which describes how traits evolve together. This matrix allows for the modeling of correlated trait evolution, unlike univariate Brownian motion, which only considers a single trait at a time.

That's a great understanding of how multivariate Brownian motion incorporates covariance between traits. Now, can you think of a scenario where the variance-covariance matrix might not be constant over time, and how that would affect the modeling of trait evolution using multivariate Brownian motion?

In scenarios where the variance-covariance matrix changes over time, the model would need to account for these temporal dynamics. This could involve using time-varying matrices or more complex models that allow for shifts in the covariance structure. Such adjustments are crucial for accurately capturing the evolution of traits that experience changing selective pressures or environmental conditions.

You've demonstrated a solid grasp of how multivariate Brownian motion can accommodate changes in the variance-covariance matrix over time. Now, can you consider how one might estimate or infer the parameters of the variance-covariance matrix from empirical data, such as phylogenetic comparative datasets, and what challenges or limitations might arise during this process?

Estimating the parameters of the variance-covariance matrix from empirical data involves fitting the model to observed trait data across species. This can be done using maximum likelihood or Bayesian methods. Challenges include ensuring the matrix is positive semi-definite, dealing with missing data, and accounting for phylogenetic relationships. Additionally, the assumption of Brownian motion might not always hold, requiring careful model validation.

You've outlined a clear understanding of the challenges involved in estimating the parameters of the variance-covariance matrix from empirical data. Can you delve deeper into the implications of violating the assumption of Brownian motion, such as how non-Brownian processes like punctuated equilibrium or adaptive evolution might affect the accuracy of multivariate Brownian motion models, and what alternative models could be used to accommodate these complexities?

Violating the assumption of Brownian motion can lead to inaccurate trait evolution models. For instance, punctuated equilibrium suggests rapid trait changes, while adaptive evolution implies directional selection. Alternative models like Ornstein-Uhlenbeck processes or models incorporating regime shifts can better capture these complexities. Thank you for the insightful discussion.

seed.source_content:
Prostaglandins were first discovered and isolated from human semen in the 1930s by Ulf von Euler of Sweden. Thinking they had come from the prostate gland, he named them prostaglandins. It has since been determined that they exist and are synthesized in virtually every cell of the body. Prostaglandins, are like hormones in that they act as chemical messengers, but do not move to other sites, but work right within the cells where they are synthesized.

Introduction

Prostaglandins are unsaturated carboxylic acids, consisting of of a 20 carbon skeleton that also contains a five member ring. They are biochemically synthesized from the fatty acid, arachidonic acid. See the graphic on the left. The unique shape of the arachidonic acid caused by a series of cis double bonds helps to put it into position to make the five member ring.

Structure of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2)

Prostaglandin Structure

Prostaglandins are unsaturated carboxylic acids, consisting of of a 20 carbon skeleton that also contains a five member ring and are based upon the fatty acid, arachidonic acid. There are a variety of structures one, two, or three double bonds. On the five member ring there may also be double bonds, a ketone, or alcohol groups. A typical structure is on the left graphic.

Functions of Prostaglandins

There are a variety of physiological effects including:

1. Activation of the inflammatory response, production of pain, and fever. When tissues are damaged, white blood cells flood to the site to try to minimize tissue destruction. Prostaglandins are produced as a result.
2. Blood clots form when a blood vessel is damaged. A type of prostaglandin called thromboxane stimulates constriction and clotting of platelets. Conversely, PGI2, is produced to have the opposite effect on the walls of blood vessels where clots should not be forming.
3. Certain prostaglandins are involved with the induction of labor and other reproductive processes. PGE2 causes uterine contractions and has been used to induce labor.
4. Prostaglandins are involved in several other organs such as the gastrointestinal tract (inhibit acid synthesis and increase secretion of protective mucus), increase blood flow in kidneys, and leukotriens promote constriction of bronchi associated with asthma.

Ball-and-stick model of the aspirin molecule, as found in the solid state. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data from Kim, Y.; Machida, K.; Taga, T.; Osaki, K. (1985). "Structure Redetermination and Packing Analysis of Aspirin Crystal". Chem. Pharm. Bull. 33 (7): 2641-2647. ISSN 1347-5223.

Effects of Aspirin and other Pain Killers

When you see that prostaglandins induce inflammation, pain, and fever, what comes to mind but aspirin. Aspirin blocks an enzyme called cyclooxygenase, COX-1 and COX-2, which is involved with the ring closure and addition of oxygen to arachidonic acid converting to prostaglandins. The acetyl group on aspirin is hydrolzed and then bonded to the alcohol group of serine as an ester.

chat_history.content: Does aspirin work by increasing the production of prostaglandins?

That's actually the opposite of how aspirin works. Aspirin is known to inhibit the production of prostaglandins, rather than increase it. Can you think about what enzyme aspirin might be targeting in order to have this effect on prostaglandin production?
Aspirin inhibits the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme, which is responsible for converting arachidonic acid into prostaglandins.

That's correct, aspirin does indeed inhibit the COX enzyme. Now, can you consider what other effects this inhibition of prostaglandin production might have on the body, beyond just reducing pain and inflammation?
Aspirin also reduces fever and prevents blood clots.

That's a great start! Reducing fever and preventing blood clots are indeed two important effects of aspirin. Can you think about how the inhibition of prostaglandin production might lead to the prevention of blood clots, specifically in terms of its effect on platelet function?

Aspirin inhibits the COX-1 enzyme in platelets, preventing the production of thromboxane A2, a prostaglandin that promotes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction. This reduction in thromboxane A2 helps to prevent blood clots.

That's a very clear explanation of how aspirin affects platelet function. Now, can you consider what potential drawbacks or risks might be associated with the long-term inhibition of COX-1 in platelets, particularly in terms of gastrointestinal health?
Long-term inhibition of COX-1 can lead to reduced production of prostaglandins that protect the gastric mucosa, increasing the risk of ulcers and gastrointestinal bleeding.

That's a well-understood potential drawback of long-term aspirin use. Can you think about how this risk might be mitigated, for example, through the development of alternative medications that selectively target the COX-2 enzyme, which is more involved in inflammation, while sparing the COX-1 enzyme and its protective effects on the gastric mucosa?

Selective COX-2 inhibitors were developed to reduce inflammation while minimizing gastrointestinal side effects. However, some of these drugs, like rofecoxib (Vioxx), were withdrawn from the market due to increased risk of cardiovascular events. Now, I understand the synthesis and structure of prostaglandins from arachidonic acid, their diverse physiological roles, and how aspirin and other painkillers inhibit their synthesis. Thank you so much for the help.

Learning Objective
1. Learn how a change in the price level affects the equilibrium interest rate.

Now let’s consider the effects of a price level increase in the money market. When the price level rises in an economy, the average price of all goods and services sold is increasing. Inflation is calculated as the percentage increase in a country’s price level over some period, usually a year. This means that in the period during which the price level increases, inflation is occurring. Thus studying the effects of a price level increase is the same as studying the effects of inflation.

Inflation can arise for several reasons that will be discussed later in this chapter. For now, we will imagine that the price level increases for some unspecified reason and consider the consequences.

Suppose the money market is originally in equilibrium at point A in Figure 7.10.1 with real money supply \(M^{S}/P_{\$}’\) and interest rate \(i_{\$}’\). Suppose the price level increases, ceteris paribus. Again, the ceteris paribus assumption means that we assume all other exogenous variables in the model remain fixed at their original levels. In this exercise, it means that the money supply (\(M^{S}\)) and real GDP (\(Y_{\$}\)) remain fixed. An increase in the price level (\(P_{\$}\)) causes a decrease in the real money supply (\(M^{S}/P_{\$}\)) since \(M_{S}\) remains constant. In the adjoining diagram, this is shown as a shift from \(M^{S}/P_{\$}’\) to \(M^{S}/P_{\$}^″\). At the original interest rate, \(i_{\$}’\), the real money supply has fallen to level 2 along the horizontal axis, while real money demand remains at level 1. This means that money demand exceeds money supply and the actual interest rate is lower than the new equilibrium rate. Adjustment to the higher interest rate will follow the “interest rate too low” equilibrium story.

More intuition concerning these effects arises if one recalls that price level increases will increase the transactions demand for money. In this version, nominal money demand will exceed nominal money supply and set off the same adjustment process described in the previous paragraph.

The final equilibrium will occur at point B on the diagram. The real money supply will have fallen from level 1 to level 2 while the equilibrium interest rate has risen from \(i_{\$}'\) to \(i_{\$}^″\). Thus an increase in the price level (i.e., inflation) will cause an increase in average interest rates in an economy. In contrast, a decrease in the price level (deflation) will cause a decrease in average interest rates in an economy.

Key Takeaways
• An increase in the price level (i.e., inflation), ceteris paribus, will cause an increase in average interest rates in an economy. In contrast, a decrease in the price level (deflation), ceteris paribus, will cause a decrease in average interest rates in an economy.

An increase in the price level would likely increase the demand for loanable funds, as the cost of goods and services rises, encouraging businesses to borrow more to finance their operations. This increased demand for loans would drive up the equilibrium interest rate, assuming the supply of loanable funds remains constant.

That's a well-reasoned argument, but let's consider the other side of the market: how might an increase in the price level affect the supply of loanable funds, and could this potentially offset the effect on demand that you mentioned?

An increase in the price level could also affect the supply of loanable funds. If the price level rises due to inflation, the real value of savings and financial assets decreases. This might discourage lenders from supplying loanable funds, as the real return on their investments would be lower. This reduction in the supply of loanable funds could potentially offset the increase in demand, leading to a more complex dynamic in the equilibrium interest rate.

You've nicely highlighted the potential effects on both the demand and supply sides of the loanable funds market. Now, considering these opposing forces, do you think it's possible for the equilibrium interest rate to actually decrease in response to an increase in the price level, perhaps if the reduction in the supply of loanable funds is significant enough to outweigh the increase in demand?

If the reduction in the supply of loanable funds is significant enough, it could potentially outweigh the increase in demand, leading to a decrease in the equilibrium interest rate. This scenario would occur if lenders become much more risk-averse due to the decreased real value of their savings, thus reducing the supply of loanable funds more than the demand increases.

That's a plausible scenario. Now, let's take it a step further: how might monetary policy, such as central bank actions, influence this dynamic and potentially alter the outcome for the equilibrium interest rate in response to an increase in the price level?

The central bank can influence the money supply, which affects the supply of loanable funds. If the central bank increases the money supply in response to rising prices (inflation), it can offset the reduction in the real value of savings, encouraging more lending and potentially increasing the supply of loanable funds. This could help to mitigate the decrease in the equilibrium interest rate. Conversely, if the central bank tightens monetary policy by reducing the money supply, it could exacerbate the decrease in the supply of loanable funds, leading to a more significant decrease in the equilibrium interest rate. Thank you for the help.

Learning Objectives
1. Explain what a value proposition is.
2. Understand why a company may develop different value propositions for different target markets.

What Is a Value Proposition?

Individual buyers and organizational buyers both evaluate products and services to see if they provide desired benefits. For example, when you’re exploring your vacation options, you want to know the benefits of each destination and the value you will get by going to each place. Before you (or a firm) can develop a strategy or create a strategic plan, you first have to develop a value proposition. A value proposition is a thirty-second “elevator speech” stating the specific benefits a product or service offering provides a buyer. It shows why the product or service is superior to competing offers. The value proposition answers the questions, “Why should I buy from you or why should I hire you?” As such, the value proposition becomes a critical component in shaping strategy.

The following is an example of a value proposition developed by a sales consulting firm: “Our clients grow their business, large or small, typically by a minimum of 30–50% over the previous year. They accomplish this without working 80 hour weeks and sacrificing their personal lives” (Lake, 2009).

Note that although a value proposition will hopefully lead to profits for a firm, when the firm presents its value proposition to its customers, it doesn’t mention its own profits. That’s because the goal is to focus on the external market or what customers want.

Firms typically segment markets and then identify different target markets, or groups of customers, they want to reach when they are developing their value propositions. Target markets will be discussed in more detail in Chapter 5. For now, be aware that companies sometimes develop different value propositions for different target markets just as individuals may develop a different value proposition for different employers. The value proposition tells each group of customers (or potential employers) why they should buy a product or service, vacation to a particular destination, donate to an organization, hire you, and so forth.

Once the benefits of a product or service are clear, the firm must develop strategies that support the value proposition. The value proposition serves as a guide for this process. In the case of our sales consulting firm, the strategies it develops must help clients improve their sales by 30–50 percent. Likewise, if a company’s value proposition states that the firm is the largest retailer in the region with the most stores and best product selection, opening stores or increasing the firm’s inventory might be a key part of the company’s strategy. Looking at Amazon’s value proposition, “Low price, wide selection with added convenience anytime, anywhere,” one can easily see how Amazon has been so successful1.

Individuals and students should also develop their own personal value propositions. Tell companies why t

chat_history.content: What is the purpose of a value proposition?
Can you think of a situation where a company would need to clearly communicate its unique benefits to potential customers, and how a value proposition might help achieve that goal?
A company might need to differentiate itself from competitors in a crowded market. A value proposition helps by clearly stating the unique value that the company offers to customers.

That's a great start! You've identified the importance of differentiation in a crowded market. Now, can you think of a specific example where a well-crafted value proposition might be the deciding factor for a customer choosing between two similar products or services?

A customer might be choosing between two streaming services. One service offers a value proposition of high-quality content with no ads and offline viewing, while the other service has a lower price but includes ads and requires an internet connection. The value proposition of the first service highlights the unique benefits of convenience and a better viewing experience, making it more appealing to customers who value these features.

That's a fantastic example! It sounds like you have a good grasp on how a value proposition can influence customer decisions. Are you interested in exploring further how companies can effectively communicate their value propositions to target audiences, and what role marketing strategies play in reinforcing these unique benefits?
I'd like to understand how companies can develop value propositions for different target markets.
How do you think a company should balance the need to tailor its value proposition to specific target markets with the risk of diluting its overall brand message or compromising its core values?

A company should conduct thorough market research to understand the unique needs and preferences of each target market. They can then create tailored value propositions that highlight the most relevant benefits for each segment while maintaining a consistent core brand message. For example, a company might emphasize convenience for busy professionals and affordability for students. This way, the company can address specific pain points without diluting its overall brand identity.

That's a well-thought-out approach! By conducting market research and creating tailored value propositions, companies can effectively speak to the needs of different target markets while maintaining a consistent core message. Can you take this idea a step further and consider how a company might prioritize which target markets to focus on when developing its value proposition, especially if resources are limited?

A company should prioritize target markets based on factors like market size, growth potential, and alignment with their core competencies. For example, a tech startup might focus on early adopters and innovators first, as they are more likely to provide valuable feedback and help refine the product. Once the product is established, the company can expand its value proposition to include mainstream users. This approach allows the company to maximize its resources and build a strong foundation before scaling up.

That's a strategic approach to prioritizing target markets! By focusing on factors like market size, growth potential, and core competencies, companies can make informed decisions about where to allocate their resources. How do you think a company should measure the effectiveness of its value proposition in different target markets, and what metrics or indicators would you use to determine whether the tailored value propositions are resonating with each audience?

A company should measure the effectiveness of its value proposition by tracking key performance indicators (KPIs) such as customer acquisition cost, customer lifetime value, and conversion rates within each target market. Additionally, they should use customer feedback and net promoter scores (NPS) to gauge satisfaction and loyalty. By analyzing these metrics, the company can determine if the tailored value propositions are resonating with each audience and make necessary adjustments. Thank you for the help.

Intent Increase confidence in changes by regularly rebuilding the system.

Problem

How do you convince your customer that you are on the right path?

This problem is difficult because:

• It can be hard to demo a software system under development, or to discuss problems with users since there is often no stable, running version of the system available.

• Integrating changes from multiple versions of a system can be slow and painful.

Yet, solving this problem is feasible because:

• You don’t have to wait until a component is “finished” before integrating it.

Solution

Institute a discipline of integrating new changes and developments on a daily basis.

Steps

• Have version management and configuration management systems in place.

• Make sure you have regression tests in place for the parts you are working on.

• Institute a discipline of short transactions for checking out system components and checking them back in again. Plan iterations to be as short as possible to allow changes to be integrated into a running system.

Tradeoffs

Pros

• You always have a working version to demo.

• You can always have a working version to run your regression tests.

• You can quickly validate your changes, thereby helping you to Build Confidence.

Cons

• You must continuously integrate changes.

Difficulties

• Large systems may have very long build times. You may need to rearchitect the system first to enable shorter build times.

• It can be hard to break some kinds of large modifications into meaningful updates that can be individually integrated.

Rationale

Many practitioners advocate a process of continuous integration as a way to avoid a risky and painful big-bang integration [Boo94].

Related Patterns

Regression Test After Every Change minimizes the risk of defects creeping in during integration.

Continuous Integration [Boo94] [Bec00] is a proven way to Always Have a Running Version.

7.07: Regression Test After Every Change

Intent Build confidence by making sure that whatever worked before still works.

Problems

How can you be sure that the last change you made won’t break the system?

This problem is difficult because:

• In a complex system, small changes can have unexpected side effects. A seemingly innocuous change may break something without this being immediately discovered.

Yet, solving this problem is feasible because:

• You have written test suites that express how the system should behave.

Solution

Run your regression test suite every time you think you have reached a stable state.

Tradeoffs

Pros

• It is easier to Always Have a Running Version.

• It is easier to Build Confidence as you proceed.

Cons

• You must relentlessly write the tests.

Difficulties

• The legacy system may not have adequate regression tests defined. To enable evolution, you will have to Grow Your Test Base Incrementally.
• Tests can only show that defects are present, not that they are absent. You may have failed to test precisely the aspect that y

Learning Objectives
• Find principal square roots and their opposites.
• Approximate square roots and find exact roots with a calculator.

Introduction

You have probably dealt with the roots of plants and trees when gardening, but did you know that there are roots in mathematics, too?

Yes, roots do exist in math. The most common root is the square root. Let’s take a look at what roots are, how they relate to exponents, and how you find the square root of a number.

Squares and Roots

To help understand square roots, let’s review some facts about exponents. Look at the table below.

Exponent Name Expanded Form
$\ 3^{2}$

“Three squared”

“Three to the second power”

$\ 3 \cdot 3$
$\ 4^{5}$

“Four to the fifth power”

“Four to the fifth”

"Four raised to the power of five"

$\ 4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4$
$\ x^{3}$

“$\ x$ cubed”

“$\ x$ to the third power”

“$\ x$to the third”

$\ x \cdot x \cdot x$
$\ x^{n}$

“$\ x$ to the $\ n$ th power”

“$\ x$ to the $\ n$ th”

“$\ x$ to the power of $\ n$”

$\ x \cdot x \cdot x_{\ldots} \cdot x$ n times

You can think of exponential numbers as “repeated multiplication.”

Just as dividing is the inverse of multiplying, the inverse of raising a number to a power is taking the root of a number. The most common root (and the one you will be studying here) is called the square root. When you are trying to find the square root of a number (say, 25), you are trying to find a number that can be multiplied by itself to create that original number. In the case of 25, you can find that $\ 5 \cdot 5=25$, so 5 must be the square root.

The symbol for the square root is called a radical symbol and looks like this: $\ \sqrt{ \quad}$. The expression $\ \sqrt{25}$ is read “the square root of twenty-five” or “radical twenty-five.” The number that is written under the radical symbol is called the radicand. Take a look at the following table.

Radical Name Simplified Form
$\ \sqrt{36}$

“Square root of thirty-six”

“Radical thirty-six”

$\ \sqrt{36}=\sqrt{6 \cdot 6}=6$
$\ \sqrt{100}$

“Square root of one hundred”

“Radical one hundred”

$\ \sqrt{100}=\sqrt{10 \cdot 10}=10$
$\ \sqrt{225}$

“Square root of two hundred twenty-five”

“Radical two hundred twenty-five”

$\ \sqrt{225}=\sqrt{15 \cdot 15}=15$

Look at $\ \sqrt{25}$ again. You may realize that there is another value that, when multiplied by itself, also results in 25. That number is -5.

$\ \begin{array}{c} 5 \cdot 5=25 \ -5 \cdot-5=25 \end{array}$

By definition, the square root symbol always means to find the positive root, called the principal root. So while $\ 5 \cdot 5$ and $\ -5 \cdot-5$ both equal 25, only 5 is the principal root. You should also know that zero is special because it has only one square root: itself (since $\ 0 \cdot 0=0$).

If you know the principal square root, you can also find its opposite. (Recall that any number plus its opposite will equal 0. So, for instance, $\ a+(-a)=0$.) In the table below, notice that while $\ \sqrt{x}$ will give

chat_history.content: Is the square root of 25 always 5, regardless of the context?

That's a good question. In real numbers, the square root of 25 is indeed 5, but can you think of any contexts, such as complex numbers or negative radicals, where the square root of 25 might not be just 5?
In complex numbers, the square root of 25 can be both 5 and -5.

That's a great point about complex numbers. However, in the context of real numbers, we often consider the square root function to have a positive value, but in some mathematical operations, the negative root is also relevant. Can you think of a situation where both the positive and negative roots of 25 would be applicable, such as in quadratic equations or algebraic expressions?
In quadratic equations, both the positive and negative roots of 25 would be applicable. For example, if we have the equation x^2 = 25, then x can be either 5 or -5.

You've provided a great example with the equation x^2 = 25. Now, can you think of a scenario where this concept of both positive and negative roots applies to a real-world problem, such as physics or engineering, where the direction or sign of a value has significant implications?

In physics, when calculating the velocity of an object under constant acceleration, both the positive and negative roots of the square of the velocity are applicable. For example, if an object is thrown upward and we want to find the time it takes to reach a certain height, we use the equation v^2 = u^2 + 2as, where v is the final velocity, u is the initial velocity, a is the acceleration due to gravity, and s is the displacement. Solving for v gives us both positive and negative roots, which correspond to the object moving upward and downward, respectively.

That's a fantastic example from physics, illustrating how both positive and negative roots can have real-world implications. Can you further explore this concept by considering what would happen if you were to calculate the velocity of an object that is thrown downward, instead of upward? How would the signs of the roots change in that scenario, and what would they represent physically?

If the object is thrown downward, the initial velocity u would be negative. The positive root would represent the velocity as the object accelerates downward, while the negative root would represent an impossible scenario where the object decelerates upward against gravity.

You've nicely applied the concept to a downward motion. Now, considering your understanding of both positive and negative roots in real-world scenarios, are you interested in exploring more complex situations, such as projectile motions under the influence of gravity, where the interplay between horizontal and vertical components of velocity might further illuminate the significance of these roots?

Learning Objectives

By the end of this section, you will be able to:

• Describe what to look for when seeking and confirming the presence of a stellar black hole
• Explain how a black hole is inherently black yet can be associated with luminous matter
• Differentiate between stellar black holes and the black holes in the centers of galaxies

Theory tells us what black holes are like. But do they actually exist? And how do we go about looking for something that is many light years away, only about a few dozen kilometers across (if a stellar black hole), and completely black? It turns out that the trick is not to look for the black hole itself but instead to look for what it does to a nearby companion star.

As we saw, when very massive stars collapse, they leave behind their gravitational influence. What if a member of a double-star system becomes a black hole, and its companion manages to survive the death of the massive star? While the black hole disappears from our view, we may be able to deduce its presence from the things it does to its companion.

Requirements for a Black Hole

So, here is a prescription for finding a black hole: start by looking for a star whose motion (determined from the Doppler shift of its spectral lines) shows it to be a member of a binary star system. If both stars are visible, neither can be a black hole, so focus your attention on just those systems where only one star of the pair is visible, even with our most sensitive telescopes.

Being invisible is not enough, however, because a relatively faint star might be hard to see next to the glare of a brilliant companion or if it is shrouded by dust. And even if the star really is invisible, it could be a neutron star. Therefore, we must also have evidence that the unseen star has a mass too high to be a neutron star and that it is a collapsed object—an extremely small stellar remnant.

We can use Kepler’s law (see Orbits and Gravity) and our knowledge of the visible star to measure the mass of the invisible member of the pair. If the mass is greater than about 3 MSun, then we are likely seeing (or, more precisely, not seeing) a black hole—as long as we can make sure the object really is a collapsed star.

If matter falls toward a compact object of high gravity, the material is accelerated to high speed. Near the event horizon of a black hole, matter is moving at velocities that approach the speed of light. As the atoms whirl chaotically toward the event horizon, they rub against each other; internal friction can heat them to temperatures of 100 million K or more. Such hot matter emits radiation in the form of flickering X-rays. The last part of our prescription, then, is to look for a source of X-rays associated with the binary system. Since X-rays do not penetrate Earth’s atmosphere, such sources must be found using X-ray telescopes in space.

In our example, the infalling gas that produces the X-ray emission comes from the black hole’s companion star. As we saw in

chat_history.content: Are black holes visible to the naked eye?

That's an interesting question. While black holes themselves are not directly visible, as they do not emit any light, what can be seen is the effect they have on the surrounding environment. Can you think of any ways in which the presence of a black hole might be indirectly observable?

A black hole can be detected by observing the behavior of nearby stars or gas. For example, if a star is orbiting an invisible object, it might be a black hole. Additionally, black holes can cause intense X-ray emissions when they accrete matter from a companion star.

That's a great start! You're on the right track by considering the effects of a black hole on its surroundings. Now, let's take it a step further: if a black hole is surrounded by a disk of hot, swirling gas, what might happen to the light emitted by that gas as it gets closer to the event horizon of the black hole?

The light emitted by the gas would be subject to gravitational redshift, where the wavelength of the light is stretched due to the strong gravitational field of the black hole. This effect can be observed as a shift in the spectral lines of the emitted light.

That's correct, the gravitational redshift would indeed cause a shift in the spectral lines. Now, considering this effect, how might astronomers use the observation of such shifted spectral lines to infer the presence and properties of a black hole, even if it's not directly visible?

Astronomers can use the Doppler shifts and spectral lines to detect binary star systems. By observing the periodic shifts in the spectral lines of a visible star, they can infer the presence of an unseen companion, such as a black hole. The pattern and magnitude of these shifts can reveal the orbital parameters and the mass of the companion. If the mass is significantly greater than what a neutron star can have (typically above 3 solar masses), it strongly suggests the presence of a black hole.

You've provided a clear explanation of how astronomers can use spectral lines to infer the presence of a black hole in a binary system. Now, let's consider another aspect: what if the black hole is not part of a binary system, but rather a supermassive black hole residing at the center of a galaxy? How might its presence be inferred in such a scenario?

In the case of a supermassive black hole at the center of a galaxy, its presence can be inferred by observing the high-velocity motions of stars or gas near the galactic center. These motions can be measured using spectroscopy, which reveals the Doppler shifts in the spectral lines of the stars or gas. By applying Kepler's laws to these observed motions, astronomers can determine the mass of the central object. If the inferred mass is extremely high (on the order of millions to billions of solar masses), it indicates the presence of a supermassive black hole. Additionally, the intense gravitational influence of the black hole can cause the stars and gas to form distinctive structures, such as accretion disks or relativistic jets, which emit strong X-ray and radio radiation.

7.5.1. Introduction

In the previous chapter, the equations for the cutting forces of the Flow Type cutting mechanism have been derived. These equation however do not take into consideration that normal forces and thus stresses may become negative and may exceed the tensile strength of the clay. If the tensile stresses exceed the tensile strength, tensile failure will occur and the clay will not fail by plastic shear failure, but by tensile failure. The failure mechanism in this case is named the Tear Type mechanism. Based on the Mohr circle, tensile cracks will occur under and angle of 45 degrees downwards with respect of the shear angle as is shown in Figure 7-26. When the blade is progressing with the cutting velocity, after a short while a so called secondary crack will occur under 90 degrees with the first (primary) crack. The model as derived in this chapter, does not assume that the tensile strength is exceeded at the moment of tensile crack forming over the full length of the tensile crack. The model assumes that the tensile strength is exceeded at the start of the tensile crack only. In order to determine whether the tensile strength is exceeded, the average shear stress in the shear plane is used. Of course there may be a stress distribution in the shear plane, leading to locally higher and lower shear stresses and thus normal stresses, but these cannot be determined with the methodology used. Only average stresses can be determined. The methodology applied however gives reasonable and practical tools to determine whether the Tear Type cutting mechanism will occur or not.

7.5.2. The Normal Force on the Shear Plane

In order to determine the normal (possibly tensile) stresses on the shear plane, first the normal force on the shear plane has to be determined.

$\ \mathrm{N}_{1}=\frac{-\mathrm{C} \cdot \cos (\alpha+\beta)+\mathrm{A}}{\sin (\alpha+\beta)}\tag{7-63}$

Substituting the equations for the cohesive force and the adhesive force gives:

$\ \mathrm{N}_{1}=\frac{-\frac{\lambda_{\mathrm{s}} \cdot \mathrm{c} \cdot \mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{i}} \cdot \mathrm{w}}{\sin (\beta)} \cdot \cos (\alpha+\beta)+\frac{\lambda_{\mathrm{s}} \cdot \mathrm{a} \cdot \mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{b}} \cdot \mathrm{w}}{\sin (\alpha)}}{\sin (\alpha+\beta)}\tag{7-64}$

The average normal stress on the shear plane equals the normal force on the shear plane N1, divided by the cross sectional area of the shear plane, giving:

$\ \sigma_{\mathrm{N} 1}=\frac{\mathrm{N}_{1} \cdot \sin (\beta)}{\mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{i}} \cdot \mathrm{w}}\tag{7-65}$

Substituting equation (7-64) in equation (7-65) gives for the normal stress on the shear plane:

$\ \begin{array}{left} \sigma_{\mathrm{N} 1}&= \frac{\sin (\beta)}{\mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{i}} \cdot \mathrm{w}} \cdot \frac{-\frac{\lambda_{\mathrm{s}} \cdot \mathrm{c} \cdot \mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{i}} \cdot \mathrm{w}}{\sin (\beta)} \cdot \cos (\alpha+\beta)+\frac{\lambda_{\mathrm{s}} \cdot \mathrm{a} \cdot \mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{b}} \cdot \mathr

chat_history.content: Does the tensile strength of clay only matter when the cutting blade is moving?
That's an interesting question. How do you think the tensile strength of clay would affect the cutting process if the blade was stationary, versus when it's in motion?

If the blade is stationary, the tensile strength might still be relevant for initial penetration, but in motion, it becomes crucial for continuous cutting and preventing crack propagation along the shear plane.

That's a great insight. Can you think of any scenarios where the tensile strength of clay might become even more critical during the cutting process, such as variations in blade speed or angle of attack?

When the blade speed is high, the tensile strength becomes even more critical because the clay has less time to deform plastically and is more likely to fail in tension. The angle of attack also plays a role; a steeper angle might increase the normal stress on the shear plane, making tensile failure more likely.

You've made some excellent connections between blade speed, angle of attack, and the importance of tensile strength in cutting clay. Now, let's consider the properties of the clay itself: how might the presence of moisture or other additives affect the tensile strength of the clay, and in turn, influence the cutting process?

Moisture can significantly reduce the tensile strength of clay, making it more prone to tensile failure during cutting. Additives can either strengthen or weaken the clay, depending on their properties. For example, organic binders might increase tensile strength, while certain chemicals might reduce it.

That's a thorough understanding of how moisture and additives can impact the tensile strength of clay. Can you take this a step further and consider how these variations in tensile strength, caused by changes in clay composition, might influence the optimal cutting parameters, such as blade speed and angle of attack, for achieving efficient and controlled cuts?

If the clay has reduced tensile strength due to moisture or additives, the optimal cutting parameters might need to be adjusted. For instance, a slower blade speed and a shallower angle of attack could help minimize tensile failure and ensure cleaner cuts. Conversely, if the clay is strengthened, faster speeds and steeper angles might be more effective. Thank you for the discussion.

Learning Objectives
• Explain how intermolecular forces affect rates of vaporization, evaporation, and condensation.

On the roof of the house in the picture below is a device known as a "swamp cooler". This piece of equipment traces its origin back to the ancient Egyptians who hung wet blankets across the doors of their homes. As the warm air passed through the blankets, water would evaporate and cool the air. The royalty went one step further and had servants fan wet cloths over jugs of water to get more evaporation and cooling.

The origin of the term "swamp cooler" is not known - they certainly don't work in a swamp. Best conditions for cooling include a high temperature (over $80^\text{o} \text{F}$) and a low humidity (preferably less than $30\%$). These coolers work well in desert areas, but don't provide any cooling in the humid areas of the country.

Evaporation

A puddle of water left undisturbed eventually disappears. The liquid molecules escape into the gas phase, becoming water vapor. Vaporization is the process in which a liquid is converted to a gas. Evaporation is the conversion of a liquid to its vapor below the boiling temperature of the liquid. If the water is instead kept in a closed container, the water vapor molecules do not have a chance to escape into the surroundings and so the water level does not change. As some water molecules become vapor, an equal number of water vapor molecules condense back into the liquid state. Condensation is the change of state from a gas to a liquid.

In order for a liquid molecule to escape into the gas state, the molecule must have enough kinetic energy to overcome the intermolecular attractive forces in the liquid. Recall that a given liquid sample will have molecules with a wide range of kinetic energies. Liquid molecules that have this certain threshold kinetic energy escape the surface and become vapor. As a result, the liquid molecules that remain now have lower kinetic energy. As evaporation occurs, the temperature of the remaining liquid decreases. You have observed the effects of evaporative cooling. On a hot day, the water molecules in your perspiration absorb body heat and evaporate from the surface of your skin. The evaporating process leaves the remaining perspiration cooler, which in turn absorbs more heat from your body.

A given liquid will evaporate more quickly when it is heated. This is because the heating process results in a greater fraction of the liquid's molecules having the necessary kinetic energy to escape the surface of the liquid. The figure below shows the kinetic energy distribution of liquid molecules at two temperatures. The numbers of molecules that have the required kinetic energy to evaporate are shown in the shaded area under the curve at the right. The higher temperature liquid $\left( T_2 \right)$ has more molecules that are capable of escaping into the vapor phase than the lower temperature liquid $\left( T_1 \right)$.

chat_history.content: Does evaporation occur faster when the temperature is lower because the molecules have less kinetic energy?

That's an interesting thought, but actually, evaporation occurs slower when the temperature is lower. Can you think about why having less kinetic energy might affect the ability of molecules to escape from the surface of a liquid?
Molecules with less kinetic energy have a harder time overcoming the intermolecular forces that keep them in the liquid state. So, fewer molecules escape as gas when the temperature is lower.

That's a great insight. You've connected the kinetic energy of the molecules to their ability to overcome intermolecular forces and escape the liquid. Now, can you take this understanding a step further and explain why an increase in temperature would lead to an increase in the rate of evaporation?
An increase in temperature means molecules have more kinetic energy, so more of them can overcome the intermolecular forces and escape as gas, leading to a faster rate of evaporation.

That's a clear explanation. Now, consider a scenario where you have two identical containers filled with the same liquid, but one is placed in a breezy area and the other is not. How might the breeze affect the rate of evaporation from the container, and can you relate this to the kinetic energy of the molecules or the intermolecular forces?

The breeze would increase the rate of evaporation by removing the water vapor from the surface of the liquid, allowing more molecules to escape. This isn't directly related to the kinetic energy of the molecules or the intermolecular forces but rather to the concentration of water vapor in the air above the liquid.

You've introduced a new factor that influences evaporation: the removal of water vapor from the surface by the breeze. That's correct, as it allows more molecules to escape without being hindered by a high concentration of vapor already present. Can you think about how this process might interact with temperature, considering that higher temperatures increase both the kinetic energy of the molecules and the capacity of air to hold water vapor?

At higher temperatures, the air can hold more water vapor, so the breeze can remove more water vapor from the surface, further increasing the rate of evaporation. This creates a feedback loop where higher temperatures lead to faster evaporation, which in turn can cool the surface due to evaporative cooling.

That's a fascinating observation about the feedback loop. Now, considering this complex interaction between temperature, kinetic energy, intermolecular forces, and the capacity of air to hold water vapor, how do you think the rate of evaporation would be affected in a scenario where the air is already saturated with water vapor, such as in a humid environment, compared to a dry environment?

In a humid environment, the rate of evaporation would be slower because the air is already saturated with water vapor. This reduces the ability of the breeze to remove water vapor from the surface, hindering the escape of additional molecules from the liquid. In contrast, a dry environment would facilitate faster evaporation due to the lower concentration of water vapor in the air, allowing the breeze to more effectively remove water vapor and enable more molecules to escape.

You've clearly understood how the saturation of the air with water vapor impacts the rate of evaporation. Now, taking into account all the factors we've discussed—kinetic energy of molecules, intermolecular forces, temperature, breeze, and air saturation—can you think of any real-world applications or natural phenomena where understanding these interactions could be crucial, such as in weather patterns, agricultural practices, or industrial processes?

Evaporative cooling in swamp coolers is a practical application. In dry climates, swamp coolers use the evaporation of water to cool the air. The water absorbs heat from the air as it evaporates, lowering the temperature. This process is more effective in dry environments because the air can hold more water vapor, enhancing the cooling effect.

Introduction

Impressionism significantly changed the process of painting, influencing artists around the world. The main passion the Impressionistic artists all shared was light and color, how the light made colors intense or changed the hue. They also wanted to capture the moment, sitting outside en plein aire, working with quick, dynamic brushstrokes on brushes loaded with paint, a new concept of nature and people, and how everything was portrayed on the canvas the impression of a view instead of smoothly blended details. The artists discovered how dark shadows, gray cloudy skies, or deep water had a continually changing variety of colors. The colors brushed with freedom formed the lines and contours, short, quick brushstrokes formed into recognizable objects.

Artists had long painted outdoors, usually sketching partial images and completing them on larger canvases or panels in the studio. The Impressionist artists want to work outside, capturing a moment in time and exploiting the natural light found plein aire. A few crucial inventions facilitated the movement. Easels had long been wooden frames an artist rested a painting on in a studio, not portable. In the 19th century, the French Box Easel was invented, portable easels set on telescopic legs, a paint box to carry supplies, and a palette built into the easel, perfect for the artist trekking through the fields and hillsides searching for the ideal light. In 1841, John Goffe Rand invented the paint tube, a revolution for artists and an essential commodity for the Impressionists. He was an artist who was aggravated by how quickly his paints dried out or spoiled. Paint, at the time, was stored in breakable glass jars or pig bladders which were not resealable and hard to use. He invented a squeezable tube made of metal, preserving the paint's fluidity and removable in small amounts. Now the artists could take tubes of different colored paint into the fields and easily squeeze out the amount they needed.

The history of the Paris salons and Impressionism were intertwined; the Salon's rejection of the set of artists forced the independent artists to circumvent the salons and create their exhibitions and destiny. The Salon held annual shows, and in 1863, 5000 works from 3000 artists were submitted for entry; only 1000 were accepted based on the traditional and expected styles of art. A few young painters had one or two paintings, still conservative paintings; however, they generally met rejection. During this time, the painters became friends, learning from each other and finding new inspiration, although they also found poverty except the few from wealthy families.

From 1874 to 1886, the Impressionists held their shows, apart from the Salon and its standards. The critics panned the artwork declaring the colors unblended, with little detail and visible brushstrokes, not artists deserving any serious attention. chat_history.content: Did the Impressionists use the same techniques as the artists before them, just with different colors?

That's an interesting question. While it's true that the Impressionists were known for their bold and vibrant color choices, did they simply adapt traditional techniques to achieve this effect, or did they also introduce new methods of applying paint and capturing light? Can you think of any ways in which the Impressionists might have broken with conventional artistic practices of their time?

They used short, thin brush strokes and precise colors to capture the light and atmosphere of a scene. They also often painted en plein air, which allowed them to capture the changing light and color of the outdoors.

That's a great start! You've identified some key techniques that the Impressionists used to achieve their unique effects. Now, let's take it a step further: how do you think painting en plein air, in particular, influenced the way the Impressionists perceived and depicted time and movement in their work?

Painting en plein air allowed Impressionists to capture the fleeting effects of light and movement in nature. This led to a focus on transient moments and a more spontaneous, less finished appearance in their paintings.

That's a wonderful insight! By capturing these transient moments, the Impressionists seemed to be conveying a sense of immediacy and impermanence. Do you think this emphasis on fleeting effects and spontaneity also influenced the way they portrayed human figures and activities in their paintings, perhaps shifting the focus away from traditional narrative or historical themes?

Yes, it did. Impressionists often depicted everyday scenes and modern life, focusing on the ephemeral moments of human activity. This shift allowed them to capture the essence of a moment rather than telling a detailed story or conveying a historical event.

That's a great observation! By focusing on everyday scenes and modern life, the Impressionists were able to create a sense of intimacy and immediacy in their paintings. Do you think this emphasis on capturing the essence of a moment, rather than telling a detailed story, also influenced the way they composed their paintings, perhaps leading to a more informal or spontaneous arrangement of figures and elements within the frame?

The Impressionists often used asymmetrical compositions and cropped figures to create a sense of spontaneity and immediacy. This approach reflected the fleeting nature of the moments they were capturing and added to the overall sense of movement and life in their paintings.

You've made a compelling connection between the Impressionists' compositional choices and their goal of capturing fleeting moments. Now, let's consider how this emphasis on spontaneity and immediacy might have influenced the emotional resonance of their paintings: do you think the Impressionists' focus on everyday life and ephemeral moments allowed them to convey a sense of quiet contemplation or introspection, or did it tend to produce a more vibrant and dynamic emotional effect in the viewer?

The Impressionists' focus on everyday life and ephemeral moments often produced a more vibrant and dynamic emotional effect. Their use of bright colors and visible brushstrokes created a sense of energy and movement, inviting viewers to engage with the scene in a lively and immediate way.

That's a great point about the energetic and dynamic quality of Impressionist paintings! However, don't you think that some Impressionist works, such as those by Claude Monet or Berthe Morisot, also convey a sense of calmness and serenity, perhaps inviting the viewer to step into a quiet, contemplative world? How do you think these artists achieved this balance between energy and tranquility in their paintings?

They achieved this balance by using soft, harmonious colors and subtle brushwork to create a sense of calmness and serenity, while still capturing the fleeting effects of light and atmosphere. This allowed them to convey a sense of quiet contemplation and introspection, even as they depicted the vibrant and dynamic world around them. Now, I think I explored all the main topics. Thank you for the help.

Molecular term symbols specify molecular electronic energy levels. Term symbols for diatomic molecules are based on irreducible representations in linear symmetry groups, derived from spectroscopic notations. They usually consist of four parts: spin multiplicity, azimuthal angular momentum, total angular momentum and symmetry. All molecular term symbols discussed here are based on Russel-Saunders coupling.

Introduction

Molecular term symbols mark different electronic energy levels of a diatomic molecule. These symbols are similar to atomic term symbols, since both follow the Russell-Saunders coupling scheme. Molecular term symbols employ symmetry labels from group theory. The possibility of an electronic transition can be deducted from molecular term symbols following selection rules. For multi-atomic molecules, symmetry labels play most of term symbols' roles.

For homonuclear diatomics, the term symbol has the following form:

$^{2S+1}\Lambda_{\Omega,(g/u)}^{(+/-)}$

whereas Λ is the projection of the orbital angular momentum along the internuclear axis: Ω is the projection of the total angular momentum along the internuclear axis; g/u is the parity; and +/− is the reflection symmetry along an arbitrary plane containing the internuclear axis. Λ may be one of the greek letters in the sequence: Σ Π Δ Φ... when Λ = 0, 1, 2, 3..., respectively. For heteronuclear diatomics, the term symbol does not include the g/u part, for there is not inversion center in the molecule.

Determining term symbols of diatomics

Let's start with CO again. As we have seen before, the molecule has a close-shell configuration. Its ground state is a totally symmetric singlet, 1Σ+, since the only possible values of (S, Λ) are (0, 0). If one of the HOMO electrons on the 5σ+ orbital has jumped to the LUMO, this molecule will be in an excited state as follows.

Suppose a CO molecule is in the excited state shown above. In order to know the term symbol of this state, a direct product of the labels is required for the two MO's with unpaired electrons. The multiplication is such as $\Pi \times \Sigma^+ = \Pi$. According to Pauli's exclusion rule, these two unpaired electrons can never share the same set of quantum numbers, therefore the spin degeneracy S can reach its maximum 3. The resulting term symbols are 1Π and 3Π.

Now if we look at O2, it does not have a close-shell configuration at its ground state. There are two unpaired electrons each occupying one of the two degenerate 2π orbitals, which can be seen in the diagram below.

The term symbol for oxygen molecule at its ground state is therefore derived such as Π x Π = Σ+ + Σ- + [Δ], as the symbol in brackets does not allow the oxygen atoms to commute.

Transition between electronic states of diatomics

chat_history.content: Are the selection rules for molecular transitions the same as for atomic transitions?

That's a great question, but before we dive into the specifics, can you first explain what you understand by 'selection rules' in the context of atomic transitions, and how you think they might apply or differ in molecular systems?

In atomic transitions, selection rules dictate which transitions are allowed based on changes in quantum numbers. For example, the Laporte rule states that transitions between states of the same parity are forbidden. In molecular systems, especially diatomic molecules, selection rules consider additional factors like changes in vibrational and rotational quantum numbers. For instance, the selection rule ΔΛ = 0, ±1 applies to electronic transitions in diatomic molecules.

That's a good start! You've identified some key aspects of selection rules in both atomic and molecular transitions. Now, can you think of how the presence of nuclear degrees of freedom, such as vibrations and rotations, might affect the symmetry considerations that underlie selection rules like the Laporte rule in molecules, compared to atoms?

In molecules, the Laporte rule is relaxed due to the lower symmetry compared to atoms. Vibrations and rotations can mix different electronic states, allowing transitions that would be forbidden in atoms. For example, in diatomic molecules, the selection rule ΔΛ = 0, ±1 comes into play, which doesn't have a direct analog in atomic systems.

That's a great insight into how molecular symmetry and nuclear degrees of freedom can influence selection rules. Can you now consider how these relaxed selection rules might impact the intensity or probability of transitions in molecules compared to their atomic counterparts, particularly in cases where vibrations or rotations are strongly coupled to electronic transitions?

In molecules, the relaxed selection rules due to lower symmetry and the involvement of vibrations and rotations can lead to a wider range of allowed transitions, potentially increasing the number of observable spectral lines. This can make molecular spectra more complex but also richer in information. The intensity of these transitions can vary significantly, with some forbidden in atoms becoming weakly allowed in molecules. This is particularly evident in resonance Raman scattering, where vibrational modes coupled to electronic transitions can lead to enhanced scattering intensities.

You've provided a clear understanding of how the relaxation of selection rules in molecules, due to their lower symmetry and the influence of nuclear degrees of freedom, affects the spectra. Now, can you delve deeper into the implications of this for spectroscopic techniques, such as fluorescence or absorption spectroscopy, where the coupling between electronic and vibrational states plays a crucial role? How might this impact our interpretation of spectral data in terms of molecular structure and dynamics?

In spectroscopic techniques like fluorescence or absorption spectroscopy, the coupling between electronic and vibrational states can lead to more complex spectra with multiple vibronic bands. This richness in spectral data allows for detailed analysis of molecular structure and dynamics. For example, the Franck-Condon principle helps predict the intensity of vibronic transitions, providing insights into the geometry changes between electronic states. Additionally, the presence of rotational structure in high-resolution spectra can offer information about molecular bonding and symmetry. Overall, the relaxed selection rules in molecules enable a more comprehensive study of their behavior through spectroscopy. Thank you for the help.

seed.source_content:
Homology

One of the key goals of sequence alignment is to identify homologous sequences (e.g., genes) in a genome. Two sequences that are homologous are evolutionarily related, specifically by descent from a common ancestor. The two primary types of homologs are orthologous and paralogous (refer to Figure 2.1411). Other forms of homology exist (e.g., xenologs), but they are outside the scope of these notes.

Orthologs arise from speciation events, leading to two organisms with a copy of the same gene. For example, when a single species A speciates into two species B and C, there are genes in species B and C that descend from a common gene in species A, and these genes in B and C are orthologous (the genes continue to evolve independent of each other, but still perform the same relative function).

Paralogs arise from duplication events within a species. For example, when a gene duplication occurs in some species A, the species has an original gene B and a gene copy B′, and the genes B and B′ are paralogus. Generally, orthologous sequences between two species will be more closely related to each other than paralogous sequences. This occurs because orthologous typically (although not always) preserve function over time, whereas paralogous often change over time, for example by specializing a gene’s (sub)function or by evolving a new function. As a result, determining orthologous sequences is generally more important than identifying paralogous sequences when gauging evolutionary relatedness.

Natural Selection

The topic of natural selection is a too large topic to summarize effectively in just a few short paragraphs; instead, this appendix introduces three broad types of natural selection: positive selection, negative selection, and neutral selection.

• Positive selection occurs when a trait is evolutionarily advantageous and increases an individual’s fitness, so that an individual with the trait is more likely to have (robust) offspring. It is often associated with the development of new traits.
• Negative selection occurs when a trait is evolutionarily disadvantageous and decreases an individual’s fitness. Negative selection acts to reduce the prevalence of genetic alleles that reduce a species’ fitness. Negative selection is also known as purifying selection due to its tendency to ’purify’ genetic alleles until only the most successful alleles exist in the population.
• Neutral selection describes evolution that occurs randomly, as a result of alleles not affecting an indi- vidual’s fitness. In the absence of selective pressures, no positive or negative selection occurs, and the result is neutral selection.

Dynamic Programming v. Greedy Algorithms

Dynamic programming and greedy algorithms are somewhat similar, and it behooves one to know the distinctions between the two. Problems that may be solved using dynamic programming are typically optimization problems that exhibit two traits: 1. optimal substructure and 2. overlapping subproblems.
